comment._content:
Hmmm - it is NOT from the top of St Phillips, according to this c.1927 map (click through to large size).

comment._content: No smoke from stacks ?? Love David Moore's photo taken from his studio

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hpeters] hmm, I think it was taken more on Napoleon or Kent St when you consider that it is the start of Sussex St we see below, as well as looking at the angle this photograph (i.e. view of Jones Bay).
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hpeters] It is an amazing photograph! :) This Hood photograph is quite overexposed which doesn't make the smoke as visible...
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Mr Hood was definitely up something tall (one of his habits!) - too early and slightly the wrong direction for the AWA Tower.

The Grafton Bond Store warehouse (see note) was about to be remodelled in the late 1920s to align with the then new Hickson Road.  Old maps show Sussex Street as a dead end at the Australian Gaslight Co.   See comments etc -

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/7007002643/]

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/7798877228/]

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Ah, then this photograph can't have been taken in Napoleon St. Then our photograph must have been before late 1920s because of the dead end.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
This reverse view about the same time (see comments) shows several warehouses near Margaret, Kent, and Napoleon Streets (on the left) which might have been Mr Hood's eyrie - 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/6888849625/]

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] haha! I see you and [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet/] :P 
Thanks for that, looks like it could've been around the same time, and it was possibly taken from around St Luke's Anglican Church. Good one!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: nla.gov.au/nla.pic-vn6300701 ; nla.gov.au/nla.pic-vn6301105 ; nla.gov.au/nla.pic-vn6300702 ; nla.gov.au/nla.pic-vn6291780 ...just for interest, here's a few pics of Darling Harbour and surrounds from the Fairfax Collection...alas, I've found that some of the captions accompanying the Fairfax Collection pics are not always correct, so the dates given might/might not be reliable...though if one wanted to be really enthusiastic it might be possible to confirm the date of some pics in the Fairfax Collection by tracking them down in the SMH and Sydney Mail...links parked here for possible future use.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
